articles.headline: Oregon Standoff Ends as Last Militant Surrenders
articles.snippet: Forty days after the occupation of Malheur National Wildlife Refuge by antigovernment protesters began, the last four holdouts gave themselves up.
articles.abstract: Forty days after the occupation of Malheur National Wildlife Refuge by antigovernment protesters began, the last four holdouts gave themselves up.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, Ore. — They implored the last holdout in the armed occupation of a wildlife refuge here to think about the Holy Spirit. They explained that the First Amendment was about freedom of speech and the Second was about the right to bear arms, and said that they were in that order for a reason. They asked him what he thought Jesus would have done in his situation.
articles.byline: By Dave Seminara, Richard Pérez-Peña and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: Pandora Is Said to Have Held Talks About Selling Itself
articles.snippet: Pandora, whose stock has fallen more than 60 percent since October, is said to be working with Morgan Stanley to meet with potential buyers.
articles.abstract: Pandora, whose stock has fallen more than 60 percent since October, is said to be working with Morgan Stanley to meet with potential buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pandora Media, the largest Internet radio service, has held discussions about selling the company, according to people briefed on the talks.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Ben Sisario

articles.headline: When Family Fortunes Beget Vicious Power Struggles
articles.snippet: The drama playing out around Sumner Redstone is the latest in a string of succession battles fought among the wealthiest of the 1 percent.
articles.abstract: The drama playing out around Sumner Redstone is the latest in a string of succession battles fought among the wealthiest of the 1 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consider the plight of Shari Redstone, the daughter of the billionaire media mogul Sumner Redstone.

articles.headline: With Shares Plunging, Deutsche Bank Sets Out to Prove It Can Be Fixed
articles.snippet: Regarded in Germany as a national asset and a symbol of economic might, Deutsche Bank now sits at the center of the “too big to fail” debate.
articles.abstract: Regarded in Germany as a national asset and a symbol of economic might, Deutsche Bank now sits at the center of the “too big to fail” debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: After John Cryan took the helm of Deutsche Bank in July, he set out to quickly clean up the mess left by his predecessors. The bank has taken earnings-crushing charges, slashed costs and pulled out of countries that it has been in for decades.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: New Fear That Central Banks Are Hindering Global Growth
articles.snippet: Investors worry that a decision by the Swedish central bank to lower its short-term rate to minus 0.50 is going to worsen the global economy.
articles.abstract: Investors worry that a decision by the Swedish central bank to lower its short-term rate to minus 0.50 is going to worsen the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: What if the bazooka is shooting blanks?

articles.headline: In Democratic Debate, Hillary Clinton Paints Bernie Sanders’s Plans as Unrealistic
articles.snippet: Defeated soundly in New Hampshire, Mrs. Clinton sought to puncture her rival’s popularity and appeal to new regions of voters.
articles.abstract: Defeated soundly in New Hampshire, Mrs. Clinton sought to puncture her rival’s popularity and appeal to new regions of voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Hillary Clinton, scrambling to recover from her double-digit defeat in the New Hampshire primary, repeatedly challenged the trillion-dollar policy plans of Bernie Sanders at their presidential debate on Thursday night and portrayed him as a big talker who needed to “level” with voters about the difficulty of accomplishing his agenda.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Eurozone Economy Grows, but Total Output Still Lags 2008
articles.snippet: Even as much of the rest of the world has bounced back from the global financial crisis, however fitfully, Europe’s economic core remains soft.
articles.abstract: Even as much of the rest of the world has bounced back from the global financial crisis, however fitfully, Europe’s economic core remains soft.
articles.lead_paragraph: Europe is still trying to crawl back to where it was in 2008.

articles.headline: When the Hospital Fires the Bullet
articles.snippet: More and more hospital guards across the country carry weapons. For Alan Pean, seeking help for mental distress, that resulted in a gunshot to the chest.
articles.abstract: More and more hospital guards across the country carry weapons. For Alan Pean, seeking help for mental distress, that resulted in a gunshot to the chest.
articles.lead_paragraph: When doctors and nurses arrived at Room 834 just after 11 a.m., a college student admitted to the hospital hours earlier lay motionless on the floor, breathing shallowly, a sheet draped over his body. A Houston police officer with a cut on his head was being helped onto a stretcher, while another hovered over the student.

articles.headline: Sunni Resentment Muddles Prospect of Reunifying Iraq After ISIS
articles.snippet: Without plans for reconciliation and rebuilding places like Anbar, critics say, the American approach risks leaving fertile ground for the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: Without plans for reconciliation and rebuilding places like Anbar, critics say, the American approach risks leaving fertile ground for the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMIRIYAT FALLUJA, Iraq — When Iraqi ground forces and American aircraft began assaulting the city of Ramadi more than a month ago, Ghusoon Muhammed and her family fled to the government’s front line, as did many other Sunni Arab families who had been trapped for months. Soldiers sent her and the children one way, and her husband another, to be interrogated in a detention facility.

articles.headline: Skid in Oil Prices Pulls the Recycling Industry Down With It
articles.snippet: As oil prices sink, it becomes cheaper to make new plastic and other materials than it is to recycle them from garbage, hitting the recycling industry hard.
articles.abstract: As oil prices sink, it becomes cheaper to make new plastic and other materials than it is to recycle them from garbage, hitting the recycling industry hard.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWARK — In a cavernous recycling facility crisscrossed with conveyor belts, enormous bales of crumpled plastic bottles are stacked one atop another, waiting to be sold to the highest bidder.

articles.headline: Battered Bank Stocks Reflect Not Just Jitters, but Mistrust
articles.snippet: The falling share price of Bank of America, Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase can be traced to investors’ deep doubts about reforms as well as to market turmoil.
articles.abstract: The falling share price of Bank of America, Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase can be traced to investors’ deep doubts about reforms as well as to market turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bear market in big United States financial stocks has many people wondering: Are we headed for another banking crisis?
